As an intern in the general medicine department, you recall a patient in the Neurology department undergoing a neurological examination where the resident asked her to close her eyes, place a 'key' on her hand, and identify/recognize it. What aspect of neurological function does this test evaluate?
questions.explanation:
Aspect of DCML System Description
Function Sensory pathway responsible for transmitting fine touch, vibration, proprioception, and pressure sensations from the body to the brain.
Pathway  
  1. First-order neurons: Sensory receptors (mechanoreceptors) in the skin, muscles, and joints transmit signals through the dorsal root ganglia to the dorsal column nuclei in the medulla.
  2. Second-order neurons: Axons of first-order neurons cross the midline in the medulla, forming the medial lemniscus. These axons ascend to the thalamus (ventral posterolateral nucleus, VPL) on the same side.
  3. Third-order neurons: Axons of second-order neurons project from the thalamus to the primary somatosensory cortex (postcentral gyrus) on the opposite side of the body.
Tract and Crossings  
  Dorsal Columns: Consist of the fasciculus gracilis (lower body) and the fasciculus cuneatus (upper body).
  Decussation: Axons cross the midline at the level of the medulla (internal arcuate fibers).
Sensory Modalities  
  Fine Touch: Discriminative touch, two-point discrimination, texture, shape recognition.
  Vibration Sensation: Perception of vibration and fine movements.
  Proprioception: Awareness of body position, joint angle, muscle tension.
  Pressure Sensation: Sensation of pressure on the skin.
Clinical Significance  
  Lesions: Lesions can lead to loss of touch, proprioception, and vibration sense on the same side of the body below the level of the lesion.
  Dermatomes: Sensory information is organized into dermatomes, which are specific regions of the skin innervated by a single spinal nerve.
  Testing: Neurological exams assess DCML function using techniques like light touch, vibration sense, and proprioception testing.
  Signs of Lesions: Patients with lesions may exhibit sensory deficits, impaired coordination, and difficulties in fine motor tasks.
Function in Perception  
  Localization: Allows for precise localization of sensory stimuli on the body.
  Texture Recognition: Enables discrimination of textures and shapes through tactile input.
  Body Awareness: Provides awareness of body position, movement, and the relative positions of body parts.

A 40-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a history of nonproductive cough and runny nose from the last 1 day. On physical examination, the patient appears comfortable. He is afebrile with a blood pressure of 110/80 mm Hg, heart rate of 50/minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on ambient air. The patient has mild pharyngeal oedema but no jugular venous distension. Auscultation of the heart reveals a slow heart rate, but it is regular with normal first and second heart sounds having no murmurs. Auscultation of bilateral lungs reveals clear breath sounds. There is neither skin rash nor pedal oedema. Admission electrocardiogram shows a 2nd-degree heart block, atrial rate of 90/minute, and ventricular rate of 50/minute. On ECG, the PR interval is the time from the onset of the P wave to the start of the QRS complex. It reflects conduction through the AV node. The normal PR interval is between 120 – 200 ms (0.12-0.20s) in duration (three to five small squares). PR interval is constant in the?

options.label: D
options.text: None of the varieties of heart block.

questions.text: An urban area population reported many cases of malaria. Which among the following is the most efficient anti-larval measures to prevent urban malaria?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning Objective
  • ➤ Recommended measures for urban malaria control: Lids of overhead tanks must be checked and maintained monthly basis; any leakage is repaired immediately. Cover-up of underground and open tanks. Open tanks used for animals should be dead-dried once in week. Never throw any containers in the open which are capable of holding water. Building by-laws be implemented to prevent fault in designs, water flow on roof, gully traps. Open tanks are treated with larvicides on weekly basis. Unused wells either be closed or treated with larvicides. Ornamental tanks and fountains are checked periodically & larvivorous fishes are introduced. Proper drainage, periodic flushing of waterlogged areas and drainage.
  • ➤ Recommended measures for urban malaria control: Lids of overhead tanks must be checked and maintained monthly basis; any leakage is repaired immediately. Cover-up of underground and open tanks. Open tanks used for animals should be dead-dried once in week. Never throw any containers in the open which are capable of holding water. Building by-laws be implemented to prevent fault in designs, water flow on roof, gully traps. Open tanks are treated with larvicides on weekly basis. Unused wells either be closed or treated with larvicides. Ornamental tanks and fountains are checked periodically & larvivorous fishes are introduced. Proper drainage, periodic flushing of waterlogged areas and drainage.
  • ➤ Lids of overhead tanks must be checked and maintained monthly basis; any leakage is repaired immediately. Cover-up of underground and open tanks. Open tanks used for animals should be dead-dried once in week. Never throw any containers in the open which are capable of holding water. questions.text: The National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP) is a centrally sponsored Health Scheme and it has been implemented with the major objective of reducing the disease burden, preventing disability, and improving awareness among the mass about Leprosy and its curability. questions.text: A community medicine student was asked to explain different types of correlation. Which among the following is the true statement regarding Correlation COEFFICIENT ?

options.label: A
options.text: Percentage change in one variable that can be explained by change in another variable

options.label: B
options.text: In a perfectly negative correlation, a rise in one variable leads to a proportionate rise in other

options.label: C
options.text: Percentage change in many variable that can be explained by change in another variable

options.label: D
options.text: In a perfectly positive correlation, a rise in one variable leads to a proportionate fall in other

questions.correct_answer: A. Percentage change in one variable that can be explained by change in another variable
questions.explanation:
Types of correlation Scatter diagram Correlation coefficient Interpretation
Perfectly positive correlation Both lines have a positive slope (at 45 degrees each); superimposed r=+1 Rise in one variable leads to a proportionate rise in other
perfectly negative correlation Both lines have a negative slope (at 45 degrees each); superimposed r=-1 Rise in one variable leads to a proportionate fall in other
Moderately positive correlation Both lines have a positive slope 0 Rise in one variable leads to a rise in other
Moderately negative correlation Both lines have a negative slope -1 Rise in one variable leads to fall in other
No (absent) correlation Both lines are perpendicular r=0 Rise/fall in one variable leads to no change in other
Spurious (false) correlation No particular pattern observed - No particular pattern observed

questions.text: A 56-year-old female presents with complaints of gradually increasing dyspnea on exertion over the past 2 years. On examination, she has an apical diastolic murmur. On further workup with echocardiography, a hockey-stick appearance is seen. Which of the following is the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Valve size

Grade of AS
  • < 1.5 – 2 cm2
  • Mild AS
  • < 1.0-1.5 cm2
  • Moderate AS
  • < 1.0 cm2
  • Severe AS

ECG

 

 Digoxin effect

Echocardiography

 

 Mitral stenosis.
  • The mitral valve's normal, biphasic, and rapid motion is altered because it opens only partly and as a single unit.
  • The posterior leaflet becomes immobile, and the anterior mitral leaflet tethering produces a "hockey stick" appearance.
  • These changes obstruct the blood flow from the atrium to the ventricle
MRI Brain

 

 Hockey-stick sign of variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
  • FLAIR image shows symmetrical pulvinar and dorsomedial thalamic nuclear hyperintensity.
  • This combination gives a characteristic "hockey-stick" appearance.

questions.text: A 63-year-old female comes to the diabetic clinic for a routine checkup. She was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type-2 and hypertension 12 years back. She was diagnosed with chronic kidney disease stage G4A2 (CKD stage 4). Which of the following is the most appropriate insulin dose adjustment required in this patient with chronic kidney disease?

A 41-year-old diabetic woman comes to her endocrinologist after she has found that her random finger-stick blood glucose level has been high on various occasions. She is already on a single drug, metformin therapy. Her temperature is 98°F, blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg and pulse is 90 beats per minute. Her HbA1c is found to be 7.2 . Her BMI is 34 , and she wants to lose the weight, but she has gained. She has a history of pancreatitis and a family history of bladder cancer in her mother. The physician talks to her regarding an additional anti-diabetic therapy. The patient does not want to take injections . Which of the following would be suitable to reduce her glucose levels?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Metformin is the first-line oral therapy for diabetic patients.
  • ↳ Patients who are unable to reduce their blood glucose levels on metformin should be started on an additional drug.
  • ↳ The choice of additional drugs depends upon several factors, including the patient’s comorbidities, drug side effects, and patient preferences.
  • ↳ Canagliflozin is a drug that has no risk of increased weight gain, no risk of pancreatitis, or bladder cancer, and can be given orally.
  • ↳ Up to 3 oral anti-diabetic drugs can be added to the regimen before considering insulin for the patient.

questions.text: A CKD patient has to undergo dialysis. His Hb is 5.2gm%, so two blood transfusions are to be given. The first bag gets completed in 2 hours . Second is started, and midway he develops shortness of breath and hypertension . His blood pressure is 180/120 mmHg, and his pulse rate is 110 beats/min. What is the cause?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ TACO occurs when pulmonary oedema develops after a blood transfusion due to circulatory overload or volume excess. TACO is particularly likely in patients who receive a large transfusion in a short time. This is true for people with cardiovascular or renal disease. Risk factors TACO: Renal impairment Hypoalbuminenia Plasma transfusion cardiac impairment Fluid overload Extremes of age Transfusion associated circulatory overload includes any four of the following occurring within 6 hours of a BT: Acute respiratory distress tachycardia increased blood pressure (BP) acute or worsening pulmonary edema and evidence of a positive fluid balance. CKD patients should have erythropoietin injections to prevent severe anaemia .
  • ➤ TACO occurs when pulmonary oedema develops after a blood transfusion due to circulatory overload or volume excess. TACO is particularly likely in patients who receive a large transfusion in a short time. This is true for people with cardiovascular or renal disease.
  • ➤ Risk factors TACO: Renal impairment Hypoalbuminenia Plasma transfusion cardiac impairment Fluid overload Extremes of age
  • ➤ Renal impairment Hypoalbuminenia Plasma transfusion cardiac impairment Fluid overload Extremes of age
  • ➤ Renal impairment
  • ➤ Plasma transfusion
  • ➤ cardiac impairment
  • ➤ Transfusion associated circulatory overload includes any four of the following occurring within 6 hours of a BT: Acute respiratory distress tachycardia increased blood pressure (BP) acute or worsening pulmonary edema and evidence of a positive fluid balance.
  • ➤ Acute respiratory distress tachycardia increased blood pressure (BP) acute or worsening pulmonary edema and evidence of a positive fluid balance.
  • ➤ Acute respiratory distress
  • ➤ increased blood pressure (BP)
  • ➤ acute or worsening pulmonary edema and evidence of a positive fluid balance.
  • ➤ CKD patients should have erythropoietin injections to prevent severe anaemia .

A 40-year-old male complains of hot flushes each time he bathes . On investigation his Hb is 20 g/dL , Platelet: 1,89,000/μL, WBC: 30,000/μL, Investigation revealed JAK2 mutation . What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Polycythemia Vera
  • Most common myeloproliferative disorder
  • It is the Neoplastic Proliferation of mature Myeloid , especially RBC.
  • JAK2 mutation
  • ↑ WBC
  • ↑ Platelets
  • ↑ Basophils
  • ↑ Histamine release → contributes to hot flushes or itching every time the patient takes a bath (aquagenic pruritis)
  • Symptoms are mainly due to Hyperviscosity
  • Blurry vision and headache.
  • Increased risk of venous thrombosis(Bud Chiari syndrome)
  • Flushed face due to congestion
  • Serum erythropoietin level below normal.
  • EPO=First investigation (JAK2 mutation is NOT specific, can occur in Essential thrombocytosis )
  • Treatment:
    • Hydroxyurea which controls cell count.
    • Phlebotomy
    • Without treatment death usually occurs within one year.

Her past manifestations of SLE have been arthralgias, hemolytic anemia, mouth ulcers , and malar rash, and she has high titers of antibodies to dsDNA. She currently is taking prednisone, 5 mg daily, and hydroxychloroquine, 200 mg daily. On examination, she is found to have a BP of 190/110 mmHg with an HR of 98 bpm. Urinalysis shows 25 RBCs per HPF with 2+ proteinuria . No RBC casts are identified. Her BUN is 90 mg/dL, and creatinine is 2.8 mg/dL (baseline 0.8 mg/dL). She has not previously had renal disease related to SLE and is not taking NSAIDs . She denies any recent illness, decreased oral intake, or diarrhea. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Initiate cyclophosphamide, 500 mg/m2 body surface area intravenously (IV), and plan to repeat monthly for 3–6 months

options.label: C
options.text: Initiate high-dose steroid therapy (IV methylprednisolone, 1000 mg daily for 3 doses, followed by oral prednisone, 1 mg/kg daily) and mycophenolate mofetil, 2 g daily

questions.correct_answer: C. Initiate high-dose steroid therapy (IV methylprednisolone, 1000 mg daily for 3 doses, followed by oral prednisone, 1 mg/kg daily) and mycophenolate mofetil, 2 g daily
questions.explanation:
Increased Progression Decreased Progression
  1. Hypertension
  2. Proteinuria
  3. Increase ds-DNA titer
  4. Low C3 complement
  5. Thrombocytopenia
  1. Anti-RO antibody
  2. Anti-LA antibody

questions.text: A 28-year-old male who had a history of throat infection a few weeks back is now presenting to the OPD with fever, headache, and unilateral swelling of the parotid gland. On examination, there are vesicles on the tympanic membrane and lymphadenopathy. He is also complaining of multiple joint pain and cough with very low sputum expectoration. What is the next best test for the given condition?

A 48-year-old obese male accompanied by his wife presents to the OPD with a history of loud, chronic snoring and gasping episodes during Sleep. He also complains of impaired concentration and memory, which interferes with his work. He always feels unrefreshed during his work. Which of the following tool is useful in assessing sleep apnea in such patients?

A 37-year-old male presented to the emergency room with a complaint of sudden-onset pleuritic right-sided chest pain. Chest radiograph shows a mild, right-sided pleural effusion . Which of the pulmonary change won't you expect in this case?

A 36-year-old man presents with complaints of dyspnea and cough for 1 week. He also developed chest pain 5 days back. Doctor orders a chest X-ray (PA view) erect and supine position, which is given below. Based on the given X-ray, what is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
A 38-year-old female patient presents to the OPD with a productive cough and dyspnoea. The CT chest of the patient is given below. Which of the following findings is shown in the CT scan?

A 65-year-old woman complains of calf pain and swelling in the leg for the last 2 days. She developed these symptoms after total knee implant surgery. Later she complains of breathlessness and dies suddenly in the ward. What is the probable cause?

A 44-year-old male comes to the emergency department with his wife with features of confusion, eye-movement disorder, and ataxia. The patient is a chronic alcoholic, hypertensive and non-diabetic. There is no history of accidents or falls. His blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg, and his pulse is 60 beats/min. Initial investigations are made , and t he patient is given IV t hia mine as a part of his treatment plan. Which of the following would be the first symptom to respond to IV Thiamine in such patients?

A 40 -year-old woman has relapsing/remitting multiple sclerosis. She has previously experienced two attacks of disease that have left her with residual lower extremity weakness. She was initially treated with glucocorticoids, with some improvement in her symptoms. However, she can only walk with a rolling walker for about 100 m. An initial antibody test shows that she is negative for reactivity to the J.C. virus. You are planning to start a disease-modifying therapy. Which of the following drug causes a maximum reduction in the appearance of new lesions and change in disease severity?
questions.explanation:
Drugs are given in MS:
HIGHLY EFFECTIVE Moderately effective
  • Natalizumab
  • Ocrelizumab

questions.text: A twenty-five years old female presents to the emergency department with the complaint of severe abdominal pain. The pain is on the upper right side and is not associated with nausea or vomiting. Examination findings include jaundice, tender hepatosplenomegaly and mild ascites. She does not have a history of any illness or trauma. What is the probable diagnosis for this patient?

A 45-year-old male patient with a history of schizophrenia has been on a first-generation antipsychotic medication for the past few months. He presents to the clinic complaining of stiffness, tremors, and difficulty with movement. The symptoms started approximately two weeks after initiating the antipsychotic medication. On examination, the patient exhibits coarse tremors in both hands, rigidity in the limbs, and a shuffling gait. His facial expression appears mask-like. There is no evidence of resting tremors or pill-rolling movements. The patient denies any history of similar symptoms in the past or a family history of Parkinson's disease. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Drug-induced Parkinsonism / Pseudo parkinsonism

  

Definition

Drug-induced movement disorder that resembles the symptoms of Parkinson's disease.

Symptoms

- Tremors (coarse)
 

- Rigidity
 

- Bradykinesia (slowness of movement)
 

- Rabbit syndrome (peri-oral tremors, usually at a later stage)

Onset

Usually occurs within days to weeks after starting a medication, especially typical antipsychotics.

Treatment

- Anticholinergic drugs:
 

- Benztropine
 

- Diphenhydramine
 

- Trihexyphenidyl
 

- Other interventions:
 

- Reducing the dose of antipsychotic drugs
 

- Changing the medication to atypical antipsychotics or low-potency typical antipsychotics

questions.text: A 32-year-old female without known significant past medical history had, for the past year, persistent psychiatric illness, facial puffiness, and a Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS) score of 40 on admission. Her thyroid profile was: Thyroid stimulating hormone – 65.71 mIU/L, Free tri-iodo threonine (FT3) – 2.2 pg/ml, free tetra iodo thyronine (FT4) – 0.5 ng/ml with normal ultrasound-thyroid. The patient was started on thyroxin 100 μg with a low dose of risperidone 2 mg. Risperidone was withdrawn over a week, and the patient was discharged on thyroxine alone with a BPRS score of 8. What does her psychiatric illness include?

The majority of the time, the patient would jump out of bed and cry "Help!" or "I'm going to die!" Occasionally, the patient would tumble off the bed, striking her head or limbs. The patient's husband described these experiences. Which age group is most likely to experience somnambulism?

Sometime later, the same intern is heard shouting at the family member of a patient, who has come to inform him that the normal saline drip given to his patient needs to be changed. questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents at the emergency department with a family member who is unconscious after hitting his head on the floor. He is a truck driver and mostly eats processed meat with low fiber, his occult blood test is positive; he has lost 3.5 kg (7 pounds) in the past two months. His mother died of endometrial cancer at age 59, and his elder brother died of colorectal cancer . He is admitted to the hospital, and a blood test reveals a very low Hb of 3.5 g/dl . Genetic testing reveals microsatellite instability . What is the most common site of single-strand mutation present in this patient?

A 43-year-old male presented with painless swelling in the right testis for 4 months. Clinical examination revealed an enlarged, firm to hard right testis. Blood tests showed normal ranges of serum tumor markers. Ultrasonography and CT scan revealed a tumor in the right testis with multiple cystic areas and an ill-defined mass. A right-sided orchidectomy was performed. Histopathological examination revealed thickened tubule walls filled with small and intermediate-sized cells . The stroma in between the tubules contained numerous dilated blood vessels and edematous stroma. What is your probable diagnosis ?

A 30-year-old man is brought to the hospital after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. He was an unrestrained passenger in a vehicle that was hit when another vehicle ran a red light. He is unconscious and was intubated on the scene. He presents to the hospital with a pulse of 120/min and a blood pressure of 85/40 mm Hg. Focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) is positive for blood within the peritoneum. He is rushed to the operating room for an exploratory laparotomy. Prior to the procedure, the anesthesiologist places a central venous catheter to assist with rapid fluid and blood product administration. Which of the following is the best technique to place a subclavian central venous catheter?

options.label: A
options.text: Insert the needle lateral to the carotid artery pulsation, pointing the needle towards the contralateral nipple

options.label: B
options.text: Insert the needle inferior to the midpoint of the clavicle, pointing the needle laterally

options.label: C
options.text: Insert the needle inferior to the midpoint of the clavicle, pointing the needle medially

options.label: D
options.text: Insert the needle medial to the sternocleidomastoid, pointing the needle laterally

questions.correct_answer: C. Insert the needle inferior to the midpoint of the clavicle, pointing the needle medially

questions.text: A 36-year-old female patient with breast cancer underwent breast conservation surgery and chemotherapy for a 1.5 × 1.2 cm estrogen receptor-positive (ER+) breast cancer with one positive axillary lymph node. She is now on the chemotherapy drug Tamoxifen. What is the best recommended follow-up for this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Routine clinical examination 3 monthly in 1st year with an annual mammogram

options.label: D
options.text: Routine clinical examination of 3 monthly and 6 monthly liver function tests

questions.correct_answer: C. Routine clinical examination 3 monthly in 1st year with an annual mammogram
questions.explanation:
Breast cancer follow-up:

Recommended for Routine surveillance
History/physical examination

 

 Every 3-6 months for the first 3 years, every 6-12 months, 4 and 5 years, and annually after that

 
Mammography

 

 Annually, beginning no earlier than 6 months after radiation therapy

 
Breast self-examination

 

 All women should be counselled to perform monthly

 
Pelvic examination

 

 Annually

 
Co-ordination of care

 

 Continuity of care with a breast cancer specialist and appropriate other health care providers.

 

Not Recommended for Routine surveillance
Routine blood test

 

 Complete blood count and LFT are not recommended

 
Imaging studies

 

 CXR, bone scan, liver USG, CT scans, FDG-PET scans, and breast MRI are not recommended for routine surveillance

 
Tumor markers

 

 Cancer antigens 15,3,27,29, AND CEA are not recommended.

questions.text: A 13-year-old male presents to the surgery OPD with complaints of soft swelling in front of his neck associated with difficulty swallowing for the last 5 months. He also reports pain in the skin around the swelling. His neck examination reveals a soft midline swelling in front of the neck, which moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. Which of the following statements is true about the given condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The most common location is sub-hyoid

options.label: C
options.text: Follicular carcinoma is seen in 1% of patients

questions.correct_answer: A. The most common location is sub-hyoid

questions.text: A 58-year-old male comes to the outpatient department complaining of hematemesis and melena . He has been suffering from abdominal discomfort and vomiting for many months. His blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg, and his pulse is 60/min. On physical examination, he is pale and thin. There are also swollen lymph nodes in the left supraclavicular region . On further evaluation with endoscopy and imaging modalities, the patient is diagnosed with a case of locally advanced gastric carcinoma . Which of the following is an investigation of choice to know the depth of cancer?
Which of the following is the first symptom manifesting in acute small intestinal obstruction ?

questions.text: A 20-year-old male has an injury to the hilum of the spleen, with devascularization of the spleen noted . The patient underwent an emergency splenectomy . Which of the following statements is true regarding the anatomy of the specimen?

options.text: The spleen lies in front of the left 9th, 10th, and 11th ribs

options.label: B
options.text: The splenic artery arises from the SMA

options.label: C
options.text: The inferior mesenteric vein empties into the right gastric vein

options.label: D
options.text: The tail of the pancreas lies in the gastrosplenic ligament

questions.correct_answer: A. The spleen lies in front of the left 9th, 10th, and 11th ribs

questions.text: In the case of acute appendicitis, pain is illustrated in the right hip on the extension of the right thigh . What is the term used to refer to this examination finding?

A 44-year-old female patient presents a progressive bloating sensation in the abdomen. She has a family history of tuberous sclerosis. Ultrasound reveals a 10cm hyperechoic mass in the left abdominal area, originating from the left kidney. CT examination reveals a mass with mixed density. Immunohistochemistry is done after a mass biopsy, which is positive for HMB-45. What is the diagnosis?

A 38-year old female presents with a picture of rectal bleeding , elimination of purulent drainage associated with a perianal tumor, pain, and weight loss. On physical examination, a large ulcerated, hard and brittle lesion was noted, which extended up to 2 cm from the anal margin, occupying the entire right Hemi-circumference, with the presence of pus, blood, and cellulitis in the gluteal region. The patient was hospitalized and underwent the endovaginal USG, which revealed a bulky mass to the right of the anal canal measuring 4.1 cm×2.4 cm with no signs of an abscess. What is the feature of this tumor?
questions.correct_answer: B. Malignant transformation in anogenital wart

questions.text: A 9-year-old female patient was brought to the clinic because of skin color changes from white to blue to red in symmetrically in bilateral h ands and feet with six months of progress. Symptoms occur once or twice a week, sometimes fortnightly, and are triggered by cold . They usually last from 10 to 15 min with spontaneous resolution. What would be the most probable diagnosis?

A 35-year-old female presents to the surgical outpatient department with complaints of palpitations, weight loss, and menstrual irregularities from the last 1 month. She underwent a near-total thyroidectomy for diffuse toxic goiter in the past and remained well for a year until similar symptoms started again. Her recent thyroid function tests are consistent with hyperthyroidism. What would be the treatment of choice for this patient?

A 23-year-old female presents with a cystic lesion in the distal body of the pancreas. On abdominal examination, no mass is palpable. Serological examination revealed serum carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) to be 2.5 ng/dL, and serum carbohydrate antigen (CA) 19.9 to be 6.7 IU/dL. Triphasic CT abdomen shows a 4.5 × 3.2 cm cystic lesion in the body of the pancreas with calcifications. The diagnosis of a mucinous cystic neoplasm is made, and the patient is admitted for laparoscopic distal pancreatectomy . Which of the following is not an advantage of advising this patient a minimal access surgery ?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ In minimally access surgery, a variety of techniques have been used to operate with less damage to the body than with open surgery. In general, minimally invasive surgery is associated with less pain, a shorter hospital stay, faster recovery, and fewer complications. Laparoscopy surgery is performed through one or more small incisions, using small telescopes and tiny cameras, and surgical instruments. It was one of the first types of minimally invasive surgery. Decreased heat loss is an advantage of this minimal access surgery.

Advantages of minimal access surgery
  • Decrease in wound size
  • Reduction in bleeding, wound infection, dehiscence, herniation & nerve entrapment
  • Decrease in wound pain
  • Improved mobility
  • Decreased wound trauma
  • Decreased heat loss
  • Improved vision
  • Faster recovery & shorter hospital stay

questions.text: A 29-year-old blind patient presents to the emergency department after sustaining a fall from a height of 5 m over a standing barrier in a stadium during a cricket match. The pulse is 104/min, blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, respiratory rate is 38/min, and the GCS is 3/15. On systemic examination, diminished breath sounds are noted on the right side. Which of the following ratios of RBCs, fresh frozen plasma, and platelets should be given to this patient for transfusion?

A 2-hour-old boy is evaluated in neonatal intensive care for a large-sized mass present at the sacrococcygeal region of the newborn. The infant is born to a 27-year-old primigravida at 36 weeks gestation by cesarean section. The mother did not seek prenatal medical care. On examination, his temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), blood pressure is 90/70 mmHg, heart rate is 118/min, and respiratory rate is 24/min . Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. Examination reveals a large-sized solid mass at the sacrococcygeal with flaccid lower extremities. A CT scan reveals a sacrococcygeal mass with a suggestion for the intraspinal extension to level L1. Subsequent MRI confirms this finding with extension to the upper lumbar spine with mass effect on ureters. The condition of the newborn is shown below in the image. Which of the following is true regarding the condition of this newborn?

A 32-year-old female patient was admitted to the hospital with severe hemorrhagic shock due to polytrauma with a hip fracture; she developed acidosis, coagulopathy, and hypothermia . Which of the following is the first line of therapy for this patient of trauma?

A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department after an accidental shotgun trauma to the abdomen . The entry wound is at the umbilical region. The pulse is 122 bpm, the systolic blood pressure is 95 mmHg , and the respiratory rate is 32/min. Which of the following measures should be taken in this patient in accordance with the CRASH-2 Trial ?

options.label: A
options.text: The dose of tranexamic acid to be administered is 5 gm IV over 10 minutes followed by 5 gm over 8 hours

options.label: B
options.text: Alteplase should be administered within 3 hours of injury

options.label: C
options.text: Tranexamic acid should be administered within 6 hours of injury

options.label: D
options.text: Tranexamic acid should be given to all trauma patients suspected to have a significant hemorrhage, including SBP < 110 mm Hg or PR > 110/min

questions.correct_answer: D. Tranexamic acid should be given to all trauma patients suspected to have a significant hemorrhage, including SBP < 110 mm Hg or PR > 110/min
questions.explanation:
CRASH-2 Trial (ATLS updates 2018)

− Use of tranexamic acid in hypotensive trauma patients

− Tranexamic acid reduces the risk of mortality from bleeding in both blunt & penetrating trauma

− Dose:1 gm IV over 10 minutes followed by 1 gm over 8 hours

− Given to all trauma patients suspected to have a significant hemorrhage, including SBP < 110 mmHg or PR > 110/min

− Should be administered within 3 hours of injury

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient underwent bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing’s disease , after which the patient developed gradual loss of vision, hyperpigmentation of the skin, and headache. Which of the following is the most likely cause?

A 45-year-old male patient has a segmental fracture of the right fibular shaft. After stabilization and wound debridement, the patient is taken to the theatre, where vacuum-assisted negative pressure is applied. Which of the following is associated with this procedure?

options.label: A
options.text: Due to negative pressure, bacterial counts decrease, and cell proliferation increases in the wound

options.label: B
options.text: Continuous pressure of +125 mm hg is applied.

options.label: C
options.text: It causes interstitial edema, thereby increasing blood flow and better healing.

options.label: D
options.text: Suitable to be used over malignancy if present over wound.

questions.correct_answer: A. Due to negative pressure, bacterial counts decrease, and cell proliferation increases in the wound
questions.explanation:
Contraindications for NPWT Use
  • Malignancy in the wound
  • Untreated osteomyelitis
  • Non-enteric & unexplored fistula
  • Necrotic tissue with eschar

questions.text: A 32-year-old female nurse present ed to the outpatient department with a complaint of left arm pain 25 minutes ago. She first noted this pain after straining to lift a patient. questions.text: A 38-year-old morbidly obese male is posted for bariatric surgery under general anaesthesia. He has been a known case of hypertension and diabetes mellitus for five years. He gives no history of any other abnormalities. He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination is unremarkable. After premedication, which of the following is the most effective method to preoxygenate this patient for denitrogenation and to delay desaturation during intubation?

options.label: A
options.text: Four vital capacity breaths over 30 seconds

options.label: B
options.text: Eight vital capacity breaths over 1 minute

options.label: D

questions.text: A 50-year-old man came to the neurology OPD with chief complaints of ataxia and abnormal eye movements. On examination, vertical gaze palsy is seen. An MRI was performed [refer to image given below]. What is the possible diagnosis?

During an exam, a medical student was shown a scintigraphy imaging of a 69-year-old woman. She was admitted to ICU with a severe lung infection and was on a ventilator. Her personal history was positive for anemia, leukopenia, photosensitive rash, and seizure disorder. She is unresponsive. Corneal, gag, and cough reflexes are absent. No motor reaction to noxious stimulation of limbs or face. Her pCO2 was 67 mm Hg, and her pH was 7.21 when mechanical ventilation assistance was removed. What does the following Tc99m-HMPAO scintigraphy image suggest?

A 20-year-old pregnant woman living in a village came to gynaecology OPD for the evaluation of her pregnancy . She has been married for six months and came to know of her pregnancy through a urine dip test. This is her first antenatal visit . The doctor takes the patient's detailed medical history and performs an obstetric examination. The patient was asked about her LMP, about which she was unsure. The doctor decided to do an ultrasound to determine her gestational age . Which of the below parameter gives an accurate assessment of gestational age ?

A 65 - years - old hypertensive patient presented to the E mergency department with sudden onset abdominal pain for one day . On physical examination, the blood pressure was 80/60 mm H g , and the ECG was normal. An Urgent CT aortogram was performed . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis ?

A 37-year-old G2P2 woman presents to the gynecologist with pain in her lower abdomen and dysmenorrhea. On a pelvic scan, a complex ovarian cyst is 4 x 5 cm in size with a ground glass appearance. She is a chronic smoker, using combined contraceptive pills, and menstrual cycles coming at intervals of 20 days since menarche. A cystectomy is done, and histology reveals endometrial glands and hemorrhage. Which of the following in the patient's history is a risk factor for her condition?

A 56-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of hot flashes, vaginal dryness, and itching since menopause. She has a family history of heart disease. She has no history of an abnormal pap smear. She is on hormone replacement therapy. Her vital signs are normal. All of the following would be expected benefits of HRT in this patient, EXCEPT?
You see four postmenopausal patients in the clinic. The patients have one condition, each listed below. Which of the following is not a contraindication to HRT?

options.label: A
options.text: Mild essential hypertension with tension headache

options.label: B
options.text: A liver disease with abnormal liver function tests

questions.correct_answer: A. Mild essential hypertension with tension headache

questions.text: A primigravida presents at 33 weeks of pregnancy with complaints of swelling in bilateral feet. She states that the swelling is worst at the end of the day and subsides by morning. Her BP is 120/74 mmHg, and cardiac examination shows normal S1 and S2. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.correct_answer: B. Bed rest with feet elevation

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, presents to the outpatient department in early pregnancy for antenatal counselling. She has a history of deep vein thrombosis of the right leg 5 years ago. She has not had any other episode of a thrombotic phenomenon since then. Her blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, and her pulse is 82/min. She is advised for thromboprophylaxis in pregnancy. This is because the risk of thromboembolism increases in pregnancy as:

options.label: B
options.text: Increased hepatic production of clotting factors

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased hepatic production of clotting factors

questions.text: What is the risk of using the contraceptive form a female purchased over the counter considering her heart condition, which is categorized as Category-4 in the WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria for contraceptive use?

options.label: C
options.text: She can use it if no other contraceptive fulfills her requirement

options.label: D
options.text: It is meant only for a particular heart condition

questions.correct_answer: B. She should not use it

questions.text: A 27-year-old gravida 2 para 1 presents to the maternity emergency with active labour at the 37th week of gestation. The patient is given a trial of vaginal delivery but undergoes a cesarean section due to the arrest of the second stage of labour. A lateral extension of an angle of the uterine incision is given during delivery of the head, which is secured. Two hours postoperatively, the patient develops abdominal distension and pallor. Pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 90/60. Physical examination shows postpartum haemorrhage. Laboratory investigation shows a drop in Hb from 10gm% to 6.5gm%. Which of the following is the next most definitive step in managing the patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. Immediate exploration in operation theatre

questions.text: A woman follows up 1 week after delivery for routine evaluation. She has no fever or abdominal pain. On abdominal examination, there are a firm globular mobile pelvic mass measuring 14 weeks in size. Vaginal examination shows bleeding not associated with foul smell, and episiotomy is healthy. Her breasts are enlarged and show milk discharge bilaterally. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Ultrasound to rule out fibroid or ovarian mass

options.label: D
options.text: Ultrasound of breasts and serum prolactin levels

questions.text: A baby is born after a difficult delivery. The paediatrician examines the baby for any nerve injuries that may have occurred in the baby as a result of undue traction. Which of the following is true of brachial plexus injuries?

options.label: A
options.text: They occur exclusively with shoulder dystocia.

options.label: C
options.text: They may result in Erb's palsy or Klumpke paralysis.

options.label: D
options.text: They frequently occur after downward traction on the posterior shoulder during delivery.

questions.correct_answer: C. They may result in Erb's palsy or Klumpke paralysis.

questions.text: An unbooked primigravida presents at term in active labour with adequate uterine contractions. On examination, the cervix is dilated 7 cm, and fetal buttocks are palpable. Soon the membranes rupture, and the breech comes out of the cervix. In which of the following conditions the after-coming head of the breech will be easily delivered?

A 28-year-old woman with PCOS undergoing fertility treatment with clomiphene citrate and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) injections complained of severe abdominal distension, nausea, vomiting, and difficulty breathing. On examination, she had moderate ascites, tachycardia, and hypotension. What is the likely cause of her current symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a potential complication.

options.label: B
options.text: The symptoms are likely related to ectopic pregnancy.

options.label: C
options.text: The patient is at high risk for ovarian torsion.

options.label: D
options.text: The findings are consistent with a normal response to fertility treatments.

questions.correct_answer: A. Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a potential complication.

questions.text: In a 43-year-old woman with heavy and frequent menstrual bleeding, an endometrial biopsy reveals endometrial hyperplasia . Among the among the given histological patterns which one poses the highest risk for developing endometrial carcinoma ?
questions.explanation:
Simple hyperplasia with out Atypia is 1%
Complex hyperplasia with out Atypia 3%
Simple hyperplasia with Atypia 8%
Complex hyperplasia with Atypia 29%

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman with primary infertility presents for evaluation. Her menstrual cycles have intervals of 40-60 days. She has normal flow and is not associated with dysmenorrhea. She is also currently on treatment for facial acne. The physician has advised certain blood investigations on day 2 of her next cycle. Which of the following biochemical findings are not expected in her case?

options.label: C
options.text: LH: FSH ratio is increased, FSH is low normal

options.label: D
options.text: Increased Sex Hormone binding globulin, Fasting insulin< 10 mIU/L

questions.correct_answer: D. Increased Sex Hormone binding globulin, Fasting insulin< 10 mIU/L

questions.text: What is true regarding elective hysterectomy planned for a 49-year-old perimenopausal female with a large uterine fibroid, heavy menstrual bleeding, and symptomatic gallstones?

options.label: A
options.text: A supracervical hysterectomy should be considered to preserve sexual function and pelvic support.

options.label: B
options.text: Cholecystectomy should not be combined with hysterectomy as it increases postoperative febrile morbidity and length of hospital stay.

options.label: D
options.text: Since the age group is likely for an endometrial malignancy, a radical Hysterectomy is a better option.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl with irregular menstrual bleeding for 3 months . Menarche at 13 years old. Cycle length varies between 35 to 45 days. Bleeding lasts for 7 to 12 days and sometimes involves heavy bleeding. Negative pregnancy test. Multiple normal ultrasounds and normal coagulation profile. Which of the following is true regarding her condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Bleeding is likely to be associated with a missed pelvic pathology and an MRI should be advised

options.label: B
options.text: Bleeding is most likely due to estrogen breakthrough

options.label: D
options.text: Cycle length increases due to a longer secretory phase

questions.correct_answer: B. Bleeding is most likely due to estrogen breakthrough

questions.text: What is the appropriate next step in management for a 14-year-old girl with no first period but normal secondary sexual characteristics ?

options.label: A
options.text: Reassure and wait for another year

questions.correct_answer: A. Reassure and wait for another year

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman who has given birth once (Para 1) visits the Gynecology department three weeks after her delivery. She has been married for two years. Her bleeding had stopped ten days after her delivery. She is currently breastfeeding her newborn and wants to know about the contraceptive options that are suitable for her. What is the recommended mode of contraception for this patient?
What is the optimal management for two 4 x 5 cm subserosal fibroids on the uterine fundus that have failed to respond to medical therapy?

A 57-year-old woman presents to the gynaecology clinic complaining of vaginal bleeding and mild fever. She had a cessation of menstruation 5 years ago. A pelvic exam shows a normal cervix. Her pap smear done 1 month prior was normal. She has no other comorbidities. USG reveals an endometrial thickness of 1mm and atrophic ovaries. What is the most probable diagnosis?

An Asian woman aged 35 years with delayed cycles and a history of primary infertility presented to the infertility clinic for an infertility workup. On laparoscopic examination, she has a normal uterus with bilateral enlarged ovaries and normal fallopian tubes; chromotubation shows blue dye spillage; however, she did not give a history of any previous pelvic infection. What is the most probable cause of patient this condition and infertility?

An infant was brought to the pediatric department for routine vaccination. After the vaccination, the mother took the baby to the doctor as she noticed the baby's asymmetrically flat head and uneven ears . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this infant?
questions.explanation:
Anencephaly Skull bones are absent & the brain parenchyma is exposed.
Brachycephaly Due to premature closure of bilateral coronal sutures.
Dolicocephaly Premature closure of the sagittal suture; produces a long and narrow skull, also known as scaphocephaly.
Plagiocephaly Asymmetrical distortion or flattening of one side of the skull
Turricephaly Cone-shaped head caused by premature fusion of coronal, sphenofrontal, and frontoethmoidal sutures
Trigonocephaly Caused by premature fusion of metopic suture → Keel-shaped forehead and hypotelorism.

questions.text: A 7-year-old female child presents to the outpatient department with difficulty chewing, teeth grinding, and difficulty in speech for six months . Her mother states that the child has a habit of sucking her thumb all the time . She has protruding front teeth on examination, and her thumb is normal. Which of the following conditions is present in children ?
questions.explanation:
Type A
  • Seen in 50% population
  • Whole digit placed inside the mouth and thumb pressing over the palate.
  • Maxillary and mandibular oral contact is maintained.
Type B
  • Seen in 13-24% 
  • Where in the thumb is placed into the cavity and mandibular and maxillary contact is maintained
Type C
  • Seen in 18%
  • Beyond the first joint of thumb placed in the oral cavity, contact with hard palate and maxillary incisors
Type D
  • Seen in 6%
  • Only little portion of thumb is placed in the mouth

questions.text: On day 4 of life, a baby girl was rushed to the emergency of the civil hospital after her mother noticed blood on a diaper while changing it. She looked for diaper rashes or any external injury but found nothing and got anxious. There was no family history of any bleeding disorder. What would be the best approach to such a case?

options.label: D
options.text: Administration of 10 ml/kg of fresh frozen plasma over 4 hours

questions.text: CME is being conducted at a medical college, and all departments are supposed to present a seminar on topics related to maternal and neonatal care . The Department of Pediatrics presents a seminar on the benefits of breast milk . While giving the seminar, they have to inform them about the benefits of the higher lactose content of breast milk. Which of the following should they mention in the benefits ?

options.label: A
options.text: Helps in the deformation of galactocerebrosides

options.label: B
options.text: Helps in the absorption of vitamin A

options.label: C
options.text: Helps in decreasing the risk of infections

options.label: D
options.text: Helps in decreasing the growth of lactobacilli

questions.correct_answer: C. Helps in decreasing the risk of infections

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is being managed in a tertiary care hospital. The pediatrician explained to the resident doctors that the patient had a partially compensated metabolic alkalosis on the arterial blood gas analysis. Her urine chloride was lower than normal , and the administration of IV normal saline improved her condition. Which of the following is the least likely cause of her acid-base derangement?
questions.explanation:
High Blood Pressure Normal Blood Pressure
  • Adrenal adenoma or hyperplasia
  • Glucocorticoid-remediable aldosteronism
  • Renovascular disease
  • Renin-secreting tumour
  • 17β-Hydroxylase deficiency
  • 11β-Hydroxylase deficiency
  • Cushing syndrome
  • Liddle syndrome
  • Bartter syndrome
  • Gitelman syndrome
  • Autosomal dominant hypoparathyroidism
  • EAST syndrome
  • Base administration

questions.text: A 2.5-year-old female child was admitted to the pediatric ward with complaints of abdominal distension and failure to thrive . She is a product of a consanguineous marriage. The patient has a history of afebrile seizures. On examination, the patient has hepatomegaly and splenomegaly without jaundice . Laboratory investigations reveal fasting blood glucose of 30 mg/dl and normal blood lactate and uric acid. SGOT and SGPT are increased. Intravenous glucagon given after a meal increases blood glucose levels. The glucagon challenge test increased random blood glucose levels but not fasting blood sugar levels . A liver biopsy was performed, which showed fat in the liver . Which enzyme is most likely defective in this patient?

A 20-day-old male boy presented to the emergency department with hypocalcemic seizures. Further examination revealed esophageal atresia, and radiography revealed a right-sided aortic arch. The doctor suspects him of a case of microdeletion of DNA sequence from chromosome 22q11.2. Which of the following features is found in this scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: Failure of development of 3 rd and 4 th Pharyngeal pouches

questions.correct_answer: A. Failure of development of 3 rd and 4 th Pharyngeal pouches
questions.explanation:
Disease Primary defect Secondary defect
DiGeorge Syndrome
  • 22q11 deletion
  • Failure of development of 3rd & 4th pharyngeal pouches
  • T-cell defect (due to thymic hypoplasia)
  • Tetany (due to parathyroid hypoplasia)
  • Congenital defects of the heart and great vessels (due to ultimo-branchial body defect)
  • Mucocutaneous candidiasis

questions.text: What diagnosis can be considered for a 6-year-old who has received multiple blood transfusions since the age of 7 months and whose blood smear shows microcytic hypochromic anemia, target cells, and decreased osmotic fragility?

A 35-year-old male presents to the office with a slow-growing mass on the tip of his nose for the last one year. The nose has a pink, lobulated, and nontender swelling on examination. There is no nasal discharge or bleeding from the mass. His picture is shown below. Which of the following is true about his condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Benign hyperplasia of sebaceous glands is seen

options.label: D
options.text: An argon laser can be used for the treatment

questions.text: A 65-year-old male comes to the clinic with a complaint of otalgia for 7 days. The patient also has a history of progressive hearing loss for 10 years. On examination, you found that there is no clear ear pathology for the pain. So, you are thinking about referred otalgia. Which of the following will be the differential diagnosis of this scenario?

A 30-year-old patient presents in the ENT clinic with complaints of decreased hearing, recurrent ear infections, and foul-smelling ear discharge. On examination, pale skin-lined granulation tissue is present behind the tympanic membrane. He is diagnosed as having cholesteatoma. Which structures are at immediate risk of damage by this condition?
questions.correct_answer: A. Long process of the incus

questions.text: A 55-years-old male presents to the physician with complaints of subtle weakness of his right lower face for 2 weeks, which he first noted while brushing his teeth. He also complains that he can no longer close his right eyelid fully, and he has increasing weakness in the remainder of his right face. Which of the following is the first nerve branch involved in this pathology?
questions.explanation:
Greater Superficial Petrosal Nerve

Secretomotor fibers to the lacrimal gland and the glands of nasal mucosa and palate

Nerve to Stapedius

Stapedius muscle

Chorda Tympani Nerve

Secretomotor fibers to submandibular and sublingual glands and brings taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue

Communicating Branch

Concha, retro auricular groove, posterior meatus, and the outer surface of the tympanic membrane

Posterior Auricular Nerve

Muscles of pinna, occipital belly of occipitofrontalis

Muscular Branches

Stylohyoid and posterior belly of digastric

Peripheral Branches- 2 Divisions:

Upper temporofacial & lower cervicofacial

All muscles of facial expression

(Temporal, zygomatic, buccal, mandibular and cervical)

Greater Superficial Petrosal Nerve

Secretomotor fibers to the lacrimal gland and the glands of nasal mucosa and palate

Nerve to Stapedius

Stapedius muscle

Chorda Tympani Nerve

Secretomotor fibers to submandibular and sublingual glands and brings taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue

Communicating Branch

Concha, retro auricular groove, posterior meatus, and the outer surface of the tympanic membrane

Posterior Auricular Nerve

Muscles of pinna, occipital belly of occipitofrontalis

Muscular Branches

Stylohyoid and posterior belly of digastric

Peripheral Branches- 2 Divisions:

Upper temporofacial & lower cervicofacial

All muscles of facial expression

(Temporal, zygomatic, buccal, mandibular and cervical)

questions.text: A 3-year-old, well-immunized boy was brought to the pediatric outpatient department with complaints of sore throat, high-grade fever, and noisy breathing with an inability to swallow for the past four hours. The physical examination showed a toxic, tachypnoeic child with inspiratory stridor. There is suprasternal, supraclavicular, and intercostal recession during inspiration . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 1-day old child is brought to the pediatrics emergency with respiratory distress and cyanosis for the past few hours. His cyanosis improves on crying. An endoscopy of the nose is done, and the following endoscopic picture is obtained: Which of the following is not true about this patient's condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Occur due to persistence of Bucco nasal membrane

options.label: B
options.text: Bilateral usually presents with respiratory difficulties

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the hospital for the follow-up of his diagnosis of Potts puffy tumor. You and your senior resident are planning for the resection of the tumor. In the nasal endoscopy, the endoscope is guided through an elevation, anterior to the middle turbinate. Your senior resident questions you, "what is that elevation?"

A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of nasal bleed 20 minutes ago. He was working in a garden when he suddenly experienced such gush of blood from the nasal cavity. He tried to stop bleed with nasal pressure but bleeding continues. An endoscopy has been ordered. Endoscopy shows bleeding in the woodruff area. Which of the following describes the location of Woodruff's plexus?

A newborn girl baby who was delivered 14 hours before is brought to the neonatology department with bilateral watery secretions from her eyes, suggesting Ophthalmia neonatorum. This type of Ophthalmia neonatorum presenting within 24 hours of birth is most likely due to which of the following possible cause?
questions.explanation:
Type

Onset age

Findings

Treatment

Chemical

<24 hr

Mild conjunctival irritation & tearing after silver nitrate ophthalmic prophylaxis

Eye lubricant

Gonococcal

2-5 days

  • Marked eyelid swelling
  • Profuse purulent discharge
  • Corneal edema / ulceration

Single IM dose of 3rd generation cephalosporin

Chlamydial

5-14 days

  • Mild eyelid swelling
  • Watery serosangulneous or mucopurulent eye discharge

PO macrolide

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents to the ophthalmologist with complaints of double vision following head trauma 1 week ago. He is standing on a stool to change a light bulb in the kitchen when he loses his balance, falls to the tiled kitchen floor, and strikes his head. He lost consciousness for less than 1 minute. He noticed diplopia immediately upon awakening. He presents to the hospital for evaluation. Cranial nerve examination reveals nerve palsy. Which feature is not seen in this patient with this nerve palsy?

A 33-year- old woman presents with a 2-day history of seeing spots floating around in her eye. Now she notes streaks of light in the same eye accompanied by a shadow in her peripheral vision that moves up and down. Her past medical history is significant for migraine headaches, but she has never had such visual symptoms with her headaches. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 23-year-old girl presents to eye OPD with the complaint of defective vision due to progressive myopia for the last 3 months. She also reports that her soft contact lenses, which were bought only 6 months back, are causing blurring of vision. Her visual acuity is 6/18 in one eye with a refraction of – 7.0/+3.5 X145. Her Slit lamp examination may show thinning and ectasia of the central cornea, opacity at the apex, Fleischer's ring at the base of the cone, and folds in Descemet's and Bowman's membranes. What could be the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A 29-year-old woman presents to ophthalmology OPD for an eye checkup with complaints of pain, photophobia, decreased visual acuity , and some redness for 4 days. The general physical examination was unremarkable. On ocular examination, vitreous floaters , edema of the retina, and choroid are observed by the ophthalmologist. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Posterior uv

questions.text: A thirteen year old girl is brought to your clinic by her mother. The girl's childhood has been complicated with developmental delays and a learning disability. Currently, she presents with decreased vision. Eye examination revealed lens subluxation. She is admitted to the hospital for further testing. Blood tests show an increased level of homocysteine. In the patient's condition, the lens is subluxated in which direction?

A 23-year-old female presents to the emergency department after she had a hit in the face with a metal instrument. She is otherwise vitally stable. And other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. On examination, a right facial laceration and contusion were noted. On examination, a fracture of the right inferior orbital rim with an associated fluid level in the maxillary sinus and significant soft tissue swelling was seen. Which of the following is true about the bone fractured in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Formed by maxillary and zygomatic bones

options.label: B
options.text: Infraorbital foramen is about 5 cm from orbital rim

options.label: C
options.text: It transmits trigeminal nerves and vessels

questions.correct_answer: A. Formed by maxillary and zygomatic bones

questions.text: A 36-year-old patient came with pain and watering in the right eye for 24 hours. On examination, a 3×2 cm corneal ulcer is seen with elevated margins, feathery hyphae, finger-like projections and minimal hypopyon in the cornea. What is the likely causative organism?

A 70-year-old man presents with progressive difficulty comprehending familiar faces, such as coworkers. He is not showing any weakness, parkinsonism, or bulbar symptoms. There is no family history of any significant illness, and there is no history of any trauma or psychiatric illness. MRI shows marked right temporal anterior atrophy, particularly involving the right anterior fusiform and Parahippocampal gyrus. The frontal and parietal lobes were relatively spared. True regarding frontotemporal dementia, are all except?

A 37 year old male patient claims that after 10 years of his marriage and satisfactory sex life, he cannot get an erection with his wife since the last 6 months. He doesn't have any extramarital affairs . He doesn't have any chronic medical illness like HTN/DM/Thyroid diseases. The consultant doctor checks which one of the following and says it's a psychological problem that he has ?

Child Tej's parents noticed his hyperactivity, impulsivity, and difficulty following orders when he was three. His parents attempted everything they could to keep his conduct under control, including confining him in his crib, verbally punishing him, and spanking him on occasion. He was regularly suspended from school and forced to relocate from one school to the next during his pre-school years because he couldn't sit still, couldn't wait for his turn, and continually disrupted other pupils in the class. He is now six years old and remains the same. What treatment options are available for Tej?
questions.explanation:
Stimulants

Nonstimulants

Methylphenidate, dexmethylphenidate

Atomoxetine

Amphetamines

Bupropion

Modafinil

Clonidine, Guanfacine
 

Venlafaxine

questions.text: A patient is presenting to the emergency room with abrupt onset of motor symptoms. The neurology resident is unable to correlate the presentation and a concrete neurological diagnosis. It also appears that the patient is not very concerned about his own symptoms. This is called:
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Dissociative Disorders
  • ➤ Dissociation or disruption in normally integrated functions of memory, identity, perception, consciousness or motor behaviour. Unconscious symptoms to escape reality or deal with anxiety Usually sudden in onset, associated with a psychological stressor
  • ➤ Dissociation or disruption in normally integrated functions of memory, identity, perception, consciousness or motor behaviour.
  • ➤ Unconscious symptoms to escape reality or deal with anxiety
  • ➤ Usually sudden in onset, associated with a psychological stressor
  • ➤ Dissociative Functional Neurological Disorder / Conversion Disorder:
  • ➤ Motor, sensory or cognitive deficit No physical cause Caused by psychological causes La Belle indifference: Lack of concern or indifference to symptom
  • ➤ Motor, sensory or cognitive deficit
  • ➤ No physical cause
  • ➤ Caused by psychological causes
  • ➤ La Belle indifference: Lack of concern or indifference to symptom
